data.event: The earliest evidence of occupation comes from two Celtic Caddy spoons found in the village in 1825.

event.title: are recorded in the Domesday Book of 1086

data.event: The two manors are recorded in the Domesday Book of 1086 one held by Abbot Sewold and the other by Arnulf de Hesding.

event.title: centuries Weston had close ties with the monks of Bath Abbey and in the late 13th century the first vicar of Weston was appointed

data.event: During the 12th and 13th centuries Weston had close ties with the monks of Bath Abbey and in the late 13th century the first vicar of Weston was appointed by the church.

event.title: leased to tenants until the dissolution of the monasteries in 1539

data.event: The land continued to be owned by the church and leased to tenants until the dissolution of the monasteries in 1539.

In 1628 it was sold to the Corporation of London although the king continued to receive rent until 1671 when it was old to Sir Walter Long, who was Member of Parliament for Bath from 1679 (the Habeas Corpus Parliament) to 1681.

event.title: 1643, some of the defeated Roundheads took

data.event: Following the Battle of Lansdowne in 1643, some of the defeated Roundheads took refuge in Weston.
